snippet: Prosecutors at the International Criminal Court in The Hague on Friday asked for another delay in starting the trial of President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya, saying that they could not proceed because the government had so far refused to hand over most...
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors at the International Criminal Court in The Hague on Friday asked for another delay in starting the trial of President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya, saying that they could not proceed because the government had so far refused to hand over most of the information they had requested.
abstract: International Criminal Court prosecutors in The Hague ask for another delay in starting trial of Kenyan Pres Uhuru Kenyatta, since the Kenyan government has so far refused to hand over most of information they have requested.

headline.main: Hague Prosecutors Ask to Delay Opening of Kenyan President’s Trial
headline.print_headline: The Hague: Prosecutors Ask to Delay Opening of Kenyan President’s Trial

snippet: The violence, in which the victims had their hands bound and their throats slit, was the latest of a string of attacks with ethnic undercurrents that comes at a time of rising political tensions.
lead_paragraph: The violence, in which the victims had their hands bound and their throats slit, was the latest of a string of attacks with ethnic undercurrents that comes at a time of rising political tensions.
abstract: More than 20 people are killed in two attacks on Kenya's coast; residents say many of the victims had their hands bound and their throats slit, latest in a string of gruesome assaults with ethic undercurrents; it is unclear who the killers are, although Shabab militants from Somalia have taken responsibility.

headline.main: Gruesome Attacks in Kenyan Villages Heighten Fears of a Nation on Edge
headline.print_headline: Gruesome Attacks in Kenyan Villages Heighten Fears of a Nation on Edge

lead_paragraph: Kenya’s opposition leaders accused the government of playing tribal politics, being numb to poverty and being caught flat-footed by terrorist attacks.
abstract: Kenya's opposition leaders gather for rally in Nairobi to commemorate the birth of country's multiparty democracy movement 24 years ago; also denounce Pres Uhuru Kenyatta's government, accusing it of playing tribal politics, being numb to poverty and being unprepared for terrorist attacks.

headline.main: Opposition Rallies Its Ranks in Kenya, Peacefully
headline.print_headline: Opposition Rallies Ranks in Kenya, Peacefully

snippet: Poachers killed an estimated 100,000 elephants across Africa from 2010 to 2012, a huge spike in the continent’s death rate of the world’s largest mammals because of an increased demand for ivory, a study found.
lead_paragraph: Poachers killed an estimated 100,000 elephants across Africa from 2010 to 2012, a huge spike in the continent’s death rate of the world’s largest mammals because of an increased demand for ivory, a study found.
abstract: Study published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences finds that poachers killed an estimated 100,000 elephants across Africa from 2010 to 2012; number represents huge spike in continent's death rate of elephants because of increased demand for ivory.

headline.main: Study Details Elephant Deaths

abstract: Investor interest remains high in Kenya, even as terrorism rages and political tensions rise; Kenya issues Africa's biggest debut Eurobond for an impressive $2 billion, and deal was so oversubscribed that cost of the loan was substantially lower than expected.

snippet: The organization reacted after Korean Airlines suspended flights to Kenya, which is not among the countries afflicted by the Ebola outbreak.
lead_paragraph: The organization reacted after Korean Airlines suspended flights to Kenya, which is not among the countries afflicted by the Ebola outbreak.
abstract: World Health Organization, seeking to quell fears that international air travel could become conduit for spreading deadly Ebola virus from Africa around the globe, says flight cancellations to Ebola-affected countries are not necessary; emphasizes that such a risk is extremely low; acts after Korean Airlines suspended flights to Kenya, which is not among the afflicted countries.

headline.main: Health Officials Try to Quell Fear of Ebola Spreading by Air Travel

snippet: Though the cashless payment system being pushed by Google would make it easier for the government to collect millions of dollars in taxes, many have resisted the change.
lead_paragraph: Though the cashless payment system being pushed by Google would make it easier for the government to collect millions of dollars in taxes, many have resisted the change.
abstract: Nairobi Journal; struggle to modernize Kenya’s unruly minibus trade in Nairobi illustrates challenges of superimposing cutting edge technology on some of poorest countries in world; Google is pushing new green transit card that will replace cash payments and track every transaction, making it easier for government to collect taxes, but many carriers and riders in are resisting or ignoring new mandate.
